channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Pension cash changes come into force
item.description: Sweeping changes to pension rules come into force which will give savers much more control over their money.

item.title: Red Cross to send planes to Yemen
item.description: The Red Cross is due to make two emergency aid flights into Yemen's capital Sanaa, as fighting intensifies in the southern city of Aden.

item.title: 80,000 'might die' in future outbreak
item.description: About 80,000 people could die if there was a "widespread outbreak" of an antibiotic-resistant blood infection, a government document says.

item.title: Tax changes spark election battle
item.description: Changes to tax, benefits and pensions coming into force spark a fresh battle between Labour and the Conservatives over whether families will be better or worse off.

item.title: Tobacco display ban in all shops
item.description: A ban on displaying tobacco products is being extended to small shops, bars and clubs, joining a similar curb on supermarkets.

item.title: Lagarde welcomes Athens payment news
item.description: International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde has welcomed the news that Athens will make a loan payment due to the IMF this week.

item.title: Teachers 'fear debates on extremism'
item.description: The NUT says teachers are fearful of discussing controversial issues, such as Islamist extremism, in the classroom.

item.title: PA rejects Israel tax transfer
item.description: Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas says he will return tax revenues unfrozen by Israel because money has been deducted.

item.title: Skin cancer 'linked to holiday boom'
item.description: A boom in cheap package holidays in the 1960s is partly behind the "worrying rise" in skin cancers in pensioners, Cancer Research UK suggests.

item.title: Murder police step up DNA screening
item.description: Police hunting the killer of an artist in a Sussex village are to knock on doors to urge more men to have their DNA screened.

item.title: Rolling Stone retracts rape article
item.description: Rolling Stone magazine retracts a 2014 article about a rape on the campus of a US university, after a report calls it "a failure of journalism".

item.title: Prince Harry arrives in Australia
item.description: Prince Harry has arrived in Australia ahead of a four-week placement with the Australian Defence Force.

item.title: Pensions shake-up and a mini-heatwave
item.description: The reforms to pensions, concerns over the way general election campaigning is heading, and forecasts of a mini-heatwave attract headlines.

item.title: Kenya's stoic survivors defy al-Shabab
item.description: The composure of the survivors of Kenya's al-Shabab attack shows how the massacre can become a unifying force, writes Andrew Harding.

item.title: Behind the scenes at Lausanne
item.description: Sleepless nights, frayed tempers and non-stop talking - Barbara Plett Usher goes behind the scenes at the Iranian nuclear talks in Lausanne.

item.title: Shared parental leave explained
item.description: The new shared parental leave rules explained

item.title: What next for the Large Hadron Collider?
item.description: The Large Hadron Collider has been re-started after a pause of two years - what will it attempt to find this time?

item.title: Prodigy score sixth number one album
item.description: Dance act The Prodigy score their sixth number one album, while Jess Glynne holds off a challenge from Ed Sheeran to top the singles chart.

item.title: Sea eagles in Orkney nesting bid
item.description: A pair of young sea eagles appear to be setting up home in Orkney, having built an eyrie among crags on the island of Hoy.

item.title: Djokovic beats Murray in Miami final
item.description: Novak Djokovic extends his winning streak against Andy Murray to seven matches with victory in the Miami Open final.

item.title: Derby defeat will define me - Carver
item.description: Newcastle boss John Carver fears losing to Sunderland will define his time in charge at St James' Park.

item.title: Celta Vigo 0-1 Barcelona
item.description: Barcelona restore their four-point lead at the top with a tense win over Celta Vigo, who end with 10 men in bizarre circumstances.

item.title: Goal of the season in one weekend?
item.description: BBC Sport takes a look at six wonder goals that were scored in the Premier League this weekend and asks: which was was best?

item.title: Holmes seals play-off win in Houston
item.description: American JB Holmes wins a three-way play-off against Jordan Spieth and Johnson Wagner to claim the Houston Open.

item.title: Asda recalls dummies over 'choke risk'
item.description: Asda recalls packs of its "Little Angels 2 Newborn Soothers 0+ Months" dummies after a customer complaint.

item.title: Osborne hails pension 'revolution'
item.description: Major changes to UK pension rules come into force on Easter Monday, in what Chancellor George Osborne calls a 'revolution'.

item.title: UK leaders condemn persecution abroad
item.description: The three main UK party leaders highlight the oppression of Christians abroad as they take a break from election campaigning to mark Easter Sunday.

item.title: Leaked memo 'one of those things'
item.description: Scottish Secretary Alistair Carmichael says the leaking of the Nicola Sturgoen memo on David Cameron is "just one of those things".

item.title: Public 'back tax rises to fund NHS'
item.description: A majority of people in Britain support tax rises as a way of funding the NHS ahead of cuts to other public services, a poll suggests.

item.title: Child heart surgery deaths 'halved'
item.description: Children's heart surgery in the UK, often the source of controversy, has improved significantly, a report has concluded.

item.title: Teachers issue energy drinks warning
item.description: Teachers warn of the risks of pupils staying up late at night and then relying on a boost from energy drinks before school the next morning.

item.title: Shared parental leave takes effect
item.description: New rights to allow parents to share maternity and paternity leave as they themselves decide following a birth or adoption come into effect.

item.title: OnLive gaming service to switch off
item.description: Video game streaming pioneer OnLive is to close after five years following the sale of several of its patents to Sony.

item.title: YouTube hack 'threatened' Bieber clips
item.description: A Russian coder reveals how he discovered a way to delete any clip uploaded to YouTube within 30 seconds.

item.title: Hadron Collider restarts after pause
item.description: The Large Hadron Collider restarts after a two-year rebuild, with scientists hoping it will provide answers to fundamental questions about the universe.

item.title: Star's birth glimpsed 'in real time'
item.description: Astronomers witness a key stage in the birth of a very heavy star, using two radio telescope views of the process taken 18 years apart.

item.title: The Voice crowns its fourth winner
item.description: Scottish firefighter Steve McCrorie wins the fourth series of TV talent show The Voice, with ratings for the final down slightly from 2014.

item.title: Craig has surgery after Bond injury
item.description: Daniel Craig has surgery after sustaining a knee injury while filming the new James Bond film, Spectre.

item.title: How is lost luggage found?
item.description: Some passengers jetting away for Easter will lose their luggage. Why does this happen and how are passengers reunited with their bags?

item.title: 10 things we didn't know last week
item.description: Mice sing love songs, and more news nuggets.

item.title: Teenagers held over terror offences
item.description: Two teenagers, aged 14 and 16, from Blackburn and Manchester are arrested by police on suspicion of terrorism offences.

item.title: Man murdered in stabbing attack
item.description: A man is killed and a woman injured in an attack at a house in Greater Manchester.

item.title: Parties launch week two of campaign
item.description: Scotland's political leaders kick off the second full week of general election campaigning when they hit the streets today.

item.title: Small shop tobacco displays banned
item.description: Legislation banning the display of cigarettes and other tobacco products in small shops in Scotland comes into force.

item.title: 11-year-old injured in crash dies
item.description: An 11-year-old boy injured in a crash in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh, on Wednesday dies in hospital.

item.title: Several shots are fired at house
item.description: A number of shots are fired at a house on the outskirts of Ballymena, County Antrim.

item.title: England education 'mismanaged'
item.description: Wales' education minister claims education in England has been mismanaged by the UK government.

item.title: Family's tribute to crash victim
item.description: A man killed in a one-car crash in Ceredigion is named by Dyfed-Powys Police.

item.title: Kenya mourns Garissa attack dead
item.description: Kenya is holding three days of mourning for the 148 victims of an al-Shabab militant attack on students at Garissa University.

item.title: Cairo bomb blast kills policeman
item.description: A bomb blast in an upmarket district of the Egyptian capital, Cairo, kills a policeman and wounds several other people.

item.title: Taliban publish Mullah Omar biography
item.description: The Afghan Taliban publish a surprise biography of the reclusive Mullah Mohammed Omar, to mark his 19th year as their supreme leader.

item.title: Search for justice after China school abuse
item.description: The BBC's Celia Hatton on sexual abuse at one school in China - and why the victims are still seeking justice.

item.title: Six Ukrainian troops killed in east
item.description: Six Ukrainian soldiers have been killed in two separate incidents in the east of the country, government officials report.

item.title: Italians rescue 1,500 migrants
item.description: The Italian coastguard and navy rescue some 1,500 migrants trying to cross into the EU via the Mediterranean Sea over a 24-hour period.

item.title: Growing fears for Chile flood missing
item.description: The death toll from Chile's floods has risen to 25, rescue workers say, amid growing concern for the 125 people still missing.

item.title: Jamaica probes police 'robber' death
item.description: Jamaica investigates the killing of a policeman shot dead by an off-duty officer after reportedly attempting an armed robbery at a bar.

item.title: Palestinians flee Damascus camp
item.description: Families flee intense fighting in the Palestinian Yarmouk refugee camp in the Syrian capital Damascus, say officials.

item.title: Obama 'confident' of Iran success
item.description: President Obama begins his push to persuade sceptical members of the US Congress to back the Iran nuclear agreement.

item.title: Lynyrd Skynyrd drummer dies in crash
item.description: Bob Burns, a founding member of rock group Lynyrd Skynyrd, dies in a car crash at the age of 64.

item.title: Death row man freed after 30 years
item.description: An Alabama man is freed after spending nearly three decades on death row, following new tests on bullets that did not link him to the crime scene.

item.title: Week in pictures: 28 March-2 April 2015
item.description: A selection of the best news photographs from around the world, taken over the past week.

item.title: Election 2015 in pictures: 2 April
item.description: Images from the campaign trail: 2 April

item.title: In pictures: Open, Youth and Mobile
item.description: Open and Youth winners in Sony World Photo Awards

item.title: Election 2015 in pictures: 1 April
item.description: Images from the campaign trail: 1 April

item.title: Weather in pictures: 31 March
item.description: Winds batter Britain causing travel disruption

item.title: No work, no football in time of Ebola
item.description: How Ebola still affects love lives and wallets

item.title: Election 2015 in pictures: 31 March
item.description: The first full day of campaigning

item.title: Llyn Padarn trwy'r tymhorau // Padarn Lake, Snowdonia through the seasons
item.description: Seasonal changes to Padarn Lake in Snowdonia

item.title: VIDEO: Finance Bill second reading
item.description: MPs pass the Finance Bill at second reading.

item.title: VIDEO: IS video claims Yarmouk capture
item.description: Islamic State militants say they have taken almost total control of Yarmouk in Syria, the Palestinian refugee camp that has been under siege for almost two years.

item.title: VIDEO: 'No justice' after son's school rape
item.description: The BBC's Celia Hatton reports on sexual abuse at one school in China - and why the victims are still seeking justice.

item.title: VIDEO: Hadron collider restarts at Cern
item.description: The Large Hadron Collider, the world's most powerful particle accelerator, has been restarted, after a two-and-a-half year upgrade.

item.title: VIDEO: Kenya grieves for Garissa victims
item.description: Kenyans have gathered at a church service in Nairobi to remember the 148 victims of an attack on students at Garissa University.

item.title: VIDEO: Pope calls for end to persecution
item.description: The Pope calls for an end to the persecution of Christians in conflict, particularly in Africa and the Middle East, in his Easter message.

item.title: VIDEO: Could tech help save the bee?
item.description: The tech which could help to unlock the secrets of the hive.

item.title: VIDEO: Turkish football team bus attacked
item.description: The bus carrying the Fenerbahce football team in Turkey has been attacked, leaving the driver injured.

item.title: VIDEO: Can technology improve traffic lights?
item.description: Fiona Trott reports on new technology giving drivers more information on - and even power to control - traffic lights.

item.title: The Victorian craze that sparked a mini-sexual revolution
item.description: The Victorian craze that sparked a mini-sexual revolution

item.title: How much? The crazy cost of children's parties
item.description: The crazy cost of children's parties

item.title: The fight to save Polish as an A-level subject
item.description: The fight to save Polish as an A-level subject

item.title: California vaping: The new subculture
item.description: The new subculture making waves in Los Angeles

item.title: The man who missed killing Hitler by 13 minutes
item.description: The man who missed killing Hitler by 13 minutes

item.title: Why don't men's trousers cover their ankles any more?
item.description: Why don't men's trousers cover their ankles any more?

item.title: Dos and Don'ts of doorstep etiquette
item.description: What to do when a politician comes calling

item.title: A supermodel in a Pakistani jail
item.description: How is Pakistani model Ayyan Ali being treated in detention?

item.title: The UK's first secret election vote
item.description: How the secret ballot spelled the end of boozy bribery
